messageBody:
Interesting idea. It sounds like something that would be very hard to do from a unit testing perspective.

One tool I've used is multithreadedtc. It doesn't really solve what you're looking for, but could help verify that code actually is thread safe. It's very low level. http://code.google.com/p/multithreadedtc

Another good trick is to use Thread.yield() often to force context switching. That makes race conditions more likely.
/ Per

________________________________
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of mraccola
Sent: Thursday, September 04, 2008 4:38 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] JUnit Concurrency Tests


I am looking for some pointers on the best JUnit extensions and/or
patterns to follow in developing concurrency tests. Basically, for
key classes I want to take my normal single-threaded JUnit tests and
execute them simultaneously on multiple threads. The goals of such a
test would be (a) to identify any concurrency issues (race conditions,
data race) and (b) to time the cost of synchronization policies.

Any tips?
